articles.headline: Biden Tries to Flip the Politics of Immigration
articles.snippet: The president has made a point of calling out Republicans for tanking the border restrictions they have demanded for years.
articles.abstract: The president has made a point of calling out Republicans for tanking the border restrictions they have demanded for years.
articles.lead_paragraph: If President Biden moves ahead with a plan to block people who illegally cross into the United States from claiming asylum, it is likely to face a swift legal challenge, much the way an effort by his predecessor in 2018 was blocked by the courts.

articles.headline: Alabama Lawmakers Move to Protect I.V.F. Treatments
articles.snippet: A court ruling declaring frozen embryos to be legally considered children has set off a scramble among leaders in both parties to preserve access to a crucial reproductive treatment.
articles.abstract: A court ruling declaring frozen embryos to be legally considered children has set off a scramble among leaders in both parties to preserve access to a crucial reproductive treatment.
articles.lead_paragraph: Alabama lawmakers are considering legislation that would protect in vitro fertilization, after a State Supreme Court ruling last week led some clinics to halt I.V.F. treatments and left many women in limbo.
articles.byline: By Eduardo Medina and Emily Cochrane

articles.headline: Netanyahu Issues First Plan for Postwar Gaza
articles.snippet: The proposal, which calls for indefinite Israeli military control and buffer zones in the territory, rankled Arab nations and was rejected by Palestinians.
articles.abstract: The proposal, which calls for indefinite Israeli military control and buffer zones in the territory, rankled Arab nations and was rejected by Palestinians.
articles.lead_paragraph: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel released on Friday his most detailed proposal yet for a postwar Gaza, pledging to retain indefinite military control over the enclave, while ceding the administration of civilian life to Gazans without links to Hamas.
articles.byline: By Patrick Kingsley and Thomas Fuller

articles.headline: Why the Cost of Success in English Soccer’s Lower Leagues Keeps Going Up
articles.snippet: Buying a small-town club offers a tempting entry to ownership. But the sport’s economics mean even multimillionaires can struggle to compete.
articles.abstract: Buying a small-town club offers a tempting entry to ownership. But the sport’s economics mean even multimillionaires can struggle to compete.
articles.lead_paragraph: Geoff Thompson knows there are plenty of people who want to buy what he has to sell. The phone calls and emails over the last few weeks have left no doubt. And really, that is no surprise. Few industries are quite as appealing or as prestigious as English soccer, and Mr. Thompson has a piece of it.

articles.headline: Their Weapons Against the Effects of Aging: Friendship, and Some Fancy Footwork
articles.snippet: The Bodacious Belles, a women’s group in Beaufort, N.C., shows the difference a network of support can make in an aging America.
articles.abstract: The Bodacious Belles, a women’s group in Beaufort, N.C., shows the difference a network of support can make in an aging America.
articles.lead_paragraph: Martha Barnes’s home was buzzing. It was a Saturday in little Beaufort, N.C., time to get ready for the town’s Mardi Gras parade, and women were zigzagging around the house, applying makeup, laughing and calling out repeatedly for the Fireball Cinnamon Whisky sitting on the kitchen counter.
articles.byline: By Colbi Edmonds and Madeline Gray

articles.headline: Sanitation Crisis in Gaza Spreads Disease
articles.snippet: “It is a public health concern,” one U.N. official said of the lack of toilets for displaced people in the territory. “But the second thing is simply just dignity.”
articles.abstract: “It is a public health concern,” one U.N. official said of the lack of toilets for displaced people in the territory. “But the second thing is simply just dignity.”
articles.lead_paragraph: In a sprawling tent encampment in Gaza, the Israeli bombs fall close enough to hear and feel. But daily life is also a struggle against hunger, cold and a growing sanitation crisis.

articles.headline: Waiting for Serhiy
articles.snippet: After nearly two years and only scraps of information, a Ukrainian family still hopes their son, a marine captured by the Russians in Mariupol, will come home soon.
articles.abstract: After nearly two years and only scraps of information, a Ukrainian family still hopes their son, a marine captured by the Russians in Mariupol, will come home soon.
articles.lead_paragraph: His attempts to escape the Russian siege had failed. He and his fellow Ukrainian marines were surrounded, dozens of miles from friendly lines. They were nearly out of food and water. Some panicked, others quietly resigned themselves to what would come next.
articles.byline: By Thomas Gibbons-Neff and David Guttenfelder

articles.headline: What Christian Traditions Say About I.V.F. Treatments
articles.snippet: While Catholic teaching expressly forbids in vitro fertilization, Protestants tend to be more open.
articles.abstract: While Catholic teaching expressly forbids in vitro fertilization, Protestants tend to be more open.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Alabama Supreme Court ruling that embryos should be considered children has forced Americans to grapple with a mess of complicated realities about law, infertility, medicine and politics.

articles.headline: Haley’s Loss to Trump in South Carolina Fuels More Doubts About Her Viability
articles.snippet: Donald Trump swept yet another early nominating contest, delivering Nikki Haley a crushing home-state loss at the hands of voters who were arguably the most familiar with her politics.
articles.abstract: Donald Trump swept yet another early nominating contest, delivering Nikki Haley a crushing home-state loss at the hands of voters who were arguably the most familiar with her politics.
articles.lead_paragraph: Read five takeaways from Donald Trump’s big win over Nikki Haley in South Carolina.

articles.headline: The Spy War: How the C.I.A. Secretly Helps Ukraine Fight Putin
articles.snippet: For more than a decade, the United States has nurtured a secret intelligence partnership with Ukraine that is now critical for both countries in countering Russia.
articles.abstract: For more than a decade, the United States has nurtured a secret intelligence partnership with Ukraine that is now critical for both countries in countering Russia.
articles.lead_paragraph: Nestled in a dense forest, the Ukrainian military base appears abandoned and destroyed, its command center a burned-out husk, a casualty of a Russian missile barrage early in the war.
articles.byline: By Adam Entous and Michael Schwirtz

articles.headline: Why Microsoft Has Accepted Unions, Unlike Its Rivals
articles.snippet: Once again a juggernaut thanks to artificial intelligence, Microsoft has worked to shed its strong-arm image. Is there a catch?
articles.abstract: Once again a juggernaut thanks to artificial intelligence, Microsoft has worked to shed its strong-arm image. Is there a catch?
articles.lead_paragraph: The December day in 2021 that set off a revolution across the videogame industry appeared to start innocuously enough. Managers at a Wisconsin studio called Raven began meeting one by one with quality assurance testers, who vet video games for bugs, to announce that the company was overhauling their department. Going forward, managers said, the lucky testers would be permanent employees, not temps. They would earn an extra $1.50 an hour.

articles.headline: Gretchen Whitmer’s Biggest Electoral Test: Can She Deliver Michigan for Biden?
articles.snippet: The Michigan governor, who has taken a prominent role in the president’s campaign, is popular in her state. But as the Democratic coalition frays, some wonder if that will be enough.
articles.abstract: The Michigan governor, who has taken a prominent role in the president’s campaign, is popular in her state. But as the Democratic coalition frays, some wonder if that will be enough.
articles.lead_paragraph: Gretchen Whitmer was planning to speak in Dearborn, Mich., at a feel-good event celebrating a health clinic founded by Muslim leaders.

articles.headline: What to Know About the Supreme Court Arguments on Social Media Laws
articles.snippet: Both Florida and Texas passed laws regulating how social media companies moderate speech online. The laws, if upheld, could fundamentally alter how the platforms police their sites.
articles.abstract: Both Florida and Texas passed laws regulating how social media companies moderate speech online. The laws, if upheld, could fundamentally alter how the platforms police their sites.
articles.lead_paragraph: Social media companies are bracing for Supreme Court arguments on Monday that could fundamentally alter the way they police their sites.

articles.headline: Supreme Court to Decide How the First Amendment Applies to Social Media
articles.snippet: Challenges to laws in Florida and Texas meant to protect conservative viewpoints are likely to yield a major constitutional ruling on tech platforms’ free speech rights.
articles.abstract: Challenges to laws in Florida and Texas meant to protect conservative viewpoints are likely to yield a major constitutional ruling on tech platforms’ free speech rights.
articles.lead_paragraph: The most important First Amendment cases of the internet era, to be heard by the Supreme Court on Monday, may turn on a single question: Do platforms like Facebook, YouTube, TikTok and X most closely resemble newspapers or shopping centers or phone companies?

articles.headline: In on the Joke at the First-Ever Florida Man Games
articles.snippet: A mullet contest, a “mud duel” with pool noodles, an “evading arrest” obstacle course — and a chance to mull why the meme that launched it all keeps hanging on.
articles.abstract: A mullet contest, a “mud duel” with pool noodles, an “evading arrest” obstacle course — and a chance to mull why the meme that launched it all keeps hanging on.
articles.lead_paragraph: The idea came to Pete Melfi, a radio personality turned podcaster in St. Augustine, Fla., last year after he organized “the laziest race in the history of races,” a .5-kilometer beer run, and the participants had a grand old time.
articles.byline: By Patricia Mazzei and Jason Andrew

articles.headline: Supreme Court Seems Wary of State Laws Regulating Social Media Platforms
articles.snippet: The tech industry argues that laws in Florida and Texas, prompted by conservative complaints about censorship, violate the First Amendment. The court’s decision could fundamentally alter the nature of speech on the internet.
articles.abstract: The tech industry argues that laws in Florida and Texas, prompted by conservative complaints about censorship, violate the First Amendment. The court’s decision could fundamentally alter the nature of speech on the internet.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court seemed skeptical on Monday of laws in Florida and Texas that bar major social media companies from making editorial judgments about which messages to allow.

articles.headline: The War in Gaza Turned This Longtime Michigan Democrat Against Biden
articles.snippet: She knows the stakes. She loathes Donald Trump. But Terry Ahwal says she won’t back President Biden in November.
articles.abstract: She knows the stakes. She loathes Donald Trump. But Terry Ahwal says she won’t back President Biden in November.
articles.lead_paragraph: Tucked down in Terry Ahwal’s basement is her personal wall of fame: Here she is at the Obama White House Christmas party. Here is a framed thank-you note from President Bill Clinton. There she is grinning alongside Jennifer Granholm, the former governor of Michigan.

articles.headline: Biden Targets a New Economic Villain: Shrinkflation
articles.snippet: Liberals prodded the president for years to blame big corporations for price increases. He is finally doing so, in the grocery aisle.
articles.abstract: Liberals prodded the president for years to blame big corporations for price increases. He is finally doing so, in the grocery aisle.
articles.lead_paragraph: On Super Bowl Sunday, the White House released a short video in which a smiling President Biden, sitting next to a table stocked with chips, cookies and sports drinks, slammed companies for reducing the package size and portions of popular foods without an accompanying reduction in price.

articles.headline: Housing Costs Are Running Hot, but Is the Data Missing a Cooling Trend?
articles.snippet: Pandemic disruptions may have muddled the measurement of home prices in inflation data. That could complicate the Fed’s course on interest rates.
articles.abstract: Pandemic disruptions may have muddled the measurement of home prices in inflation data. That could complicate the Fed’s course on interest rates.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Federal Reserve may have a housing problem. At the very least, it has a housing riddle.
